I think that this entry did an excellent job enticing me to read the book. I agree that Pessl's "Night Film" can be described as a future book because of the extrasensory details that the book includes in order to involve the reader in the story.
 
 
 
 I think it meets the challenge of the assignment because it has expertly addressed every aspect of the project and made me want to go out and read this book!

I would have been interested to read an entry about something other than the style of books that we've already been reading in class, which is what I felt this entry felt like. I don't really have anything else to suggest, I think this article was done really well and its the best one that I reviewed!
This entry meets the challenge of the assignment because I believe that it is a representation of a future book, albeit for personal reasons only.

This entry is not for something that I think everyone can relate to, nor is it something that I think everyone would be interested. I do believe that this is an example of a future book, but I think this entry falls short in every other aspect. I appreciate the fact that this is a more personal example, but I don't think it fits the assignment.
 
 
 
 I think that this can be improved by choosing a topic that everyone can relate to. This is a narrow topic of an example of a future book for one individual, but not for everyone. In this scenario I'm still seeing people having to go out and buy books instead of having easier access to them like ebooks.

I think that the author of this entry was feeling very strong about the book that s/he chose. This allowed for a more passionate feeling about the book which makes the reader of this entry want to read the book and to see the accompanying film and apps! I think its really cool that this book has other platforms that go along with it aside from just different pictures like we saw in "A Dodo at Oxford". This ties the book to more recent modes of media which I found very interesting.

If anything, I felt like this could have used more detail in order to make it a little bit longer. The length and the voice of the entry didn't seem to go hand in hand. I felt the passion that was coming through in the writing, but then it ended before I wanted to.

I think the subject of this entry is very interesting and is something that I would enjoy taking a look at. Its also a reference to some iconic pop culture which I think will still be relevant in the future. I think this meets the challenge of the assignment because it ties together the past and the future in a way that I think could be relevant for anyone.

I really wanted to see pictures! I loved the description of the book itself, but I wanted to actually see something instead of just reading about the aesthetics of the book. Also, this definitely needs a more concrete title. The title seems as if this was submitted on accident or out of confusion. Also, please remove "the subject of this entry" because that is self-explanatory.

This entry is about documentaries with a primary focus on the "Babies" documentary film. I liked this entry because I felt like it gave a different spin on the project while still meeting the assignment. This is definitely an example of the future of the book. I could see people in the future choosing to watch documentaries to learn about things instead of reading books. As it is, things like furniture and special dog collars already come with DVDs to show you how to use them correctly.

I think a way to really improve this would be to include videos in this entry. This field guide is an online field guide, so it only makes sense to provide links to videos that would help show how documentaries will be the future of the book. 
 
 
 
 "Take for example" in the summary doesn't fit with the rest of the assignment, it is self-explanatory. Also, choose what you want your focus to be on- do you want it on "Babies" or on documentaries as a whole? If you choose to focus more on "Babies", then include it in your conclusion of how this is a future book. If you choose to focus on documentaries on a whole, then I would omit the reference to "Babies" and include clips from different documentaries to prove your point.

I really enjoyed the description of how Gaiman reads the script of the book. I thought the summary was straight and to the point as it should have been - easy to understand and immediately know what I was going to read about. As someone familiar with Gaiman's style, but who has not listened to this book, the description of his "acting" skills piqued my interested in the project and made me go and physically look up the project online after I finished reading the entry, so I feel that that aspect of the description was well done. It was also helpful to find out a bit of the background of the book, which unlike many other stories is very unique. (which was also an aspect of the assignment, just as the voice of the piece and attempting to motivate people to go and read the piece was). I also felt that the last line of the future section was particularly effective and was a lovely way to end the section by tying in themes of the Gaiman's pieces.

I think the piece is off to a very good start, in general I think there are just a few places that could be expanded upon with some greater detail. As the author mentions the presentation of the book is unique as an audio book, so in addition the description of Gaiman's voice as the author has done which is very well done, the argument would benefit from describing how that unique experience of being read to instead of reading; not being separated from the author by your own voice, pacing, and tone of reading, or physical page, but instead almost having a "tangible" connection to the author and the authors voice changes the reading experience as only an audio book can. Doing so would help to further drive home the point that audio books are a entirely unique experience. I would have also like to have a scene a little bit of a deeper analysis on how audio books could expand reading in the future - again, drive home the point that this format can uniquely change the reading experience over other mediums, not just save time as the author rightfully mentioned.

I specifically thought the description that focused on the Alice program was direct, easy to follow and clearly showed how the program furthered the reading experience through an immersive experience for the reader - it was the most effective and impactful description and really showed how books can incorporate future technology in order to evolve.

Because the programs are very unique and many readers could be unfamiliar with their concepts I feel that the first two programs, Nelson and Coupland could have benefitted from an expanded description. I understand that the limited word space requires succinct phrasing, and the current descriptions do a fine job of describing the programs actual functions, but specific examples of something a reader could do while using the app (instead of just describing general functions) and how it would benefit the reader might have clarified the apps purpose and place in the future of the book, making the description a bit easier to understand, especially to those who are unfamiliar with the programs.

I greatly appreciated the use of senses to describe the unique elements of the website in the description section - I also wrote about Pottermore and that was not something I had thought about including in my own description but it really helped to sell the complete atmosphere the site provides not just in content but all the way to its attention to ambiance, which is something unique to web and audio formats that can not be included in the book. The sensory details helped set the stage for the following descriptions of the types of activities users can participate in on the site, helping to show how immersive and expansive the site is and truly showing how individual it is. The summary is also very clear and direct, the reader knows exactly what the entry will be about and what to expect in the following sections.

While I like the ideas and direction of the "future book" entry, I think it would benefit from a slightly stronger focus on how this can shape the direction of books and readership. The author mentions that this idea could be applied to other books and other genres, it would be worth it to consider how one could do so, how could authors make the interaction for books uniquely individual like Rowling did, and what will that do for reading - will being able to participate in such and interactive and immersive world drastically change how people read? There are several interesting and unique applications this type of site has to books in the future and I think the analysis of the future section could benefit from some slightly deeper analysis to truly convince readers how this could change reading forever.

I thought the description of just what makes Pottermore a future book was well crafted and straight to the point. Not only did it show how it represents something new in the formatting and use of books by explaining the interactive websites use as a digital extension of the printed world to be used in conjunction with the books, but it mentioned why this was successful - people depend upon technology. In the other posts I have read, not many authors focused on why their type of book was sustainable and successful for the future of books; this post did in an well though out sentence. Such an explanation helps to solidify the potential of this type of medium and why it could feasibly be incorporated into other books and other genres as people become more and more familiar with and dependent upon technology.

I would really have liked to see the author expand the "asthetics" portion of the description section. The general descriptions of what users can accomplish on Pottermore is direct and well written, but I think those not familiar with the site would be more intrigued if the author were to mention what the site looks like, how its set up (use of the sorting hat and the house systems with quizzes and games, common rooms to interact with other users in, the easter eggs in the interactive sections of the novels etc). This set-up is part of the large appeal of Pottermore and is crucial to it's success as an interactive site, so I feel that some attention does need to be given to it's physical appearance and practical uses in the description section.

I thought the focus on the emotional reaction of the reader based on the text was intriguing and a very interesting way to show readers that the future of the books does not necessarily have to involve technology in a traditional way. The descriptions of the multiple formats and uses of texts (and their purposes) truly showed not only the versatility of font and format, but its importance, and just how deeply the presentation of words in a story can effect the readers emotional well being or reflect the state of the character or the world of the book in a visceral way. The idea that the technological advances of books does not have to mean their conversion to ebooks or their forced incorporation of technology was interesting and well presented.

While the description of the types of fonts and formats is well presented and well reasoned, if feel including more detail of just how the use of those tools effects the emotional response/connection to the work of the reader would have helped sell the appeal of this type of book more. By just focusing on the detailed and complex uses of the font and format (while informative, important and well done in the original post) the book can come off as daunting or confusing, which may work for some readers, but in general feels like a hard sell to get people interested. By incorporating how those techniques create a unique and intriguing experience for the reader however, and why that experience of House of Leaves is unique, people might be far more willing to go into the book with an open mind and spirit and not be turned off to the idea of this type of media in general.
The strength of your rough draft is that you explained the usages of a blog very thoroughly and what a blog encompasses.

Unless I read the title of your subject, I would not have understood what you were necessarily writing about, I kept waiting to read which particularblog you were discussing, however, you were speaking generally about blogs as a whole. Possibly bring up an example of a blog group that you have found very useful or interesting so that the reader could be directed to those and they could experience what you are describing. You spoke of tragedies, possibly reference where you read about a child drowning or cancer that struck you so interesting that you mentioned it here.

The strength of your draft are that you clearly describe the journey of Emily C. chronologically detailing her story as a vegan, among other aspects of that such as including recipes. I also found it strong that you mentioned howe-books are the wave of the future and the items that are now extinct that once captured memories.

The weakness of your paper is that you started off strong regarding Emily C. however finished somewhat generic with discussing an entire realm of futuristic literature. I am conflicted here because I do feel that the information you stated was important (one of the strengths I listed above) yet, I think you should find a more solid connection with Emilys journey. You mentioned that she was not associated with a publishing company, did she attempt to be published? Was publication a more difficult choice to spreading her story than e-book? I believe the convenience of publication online could be discussed, wherein that is also important to why she most likely decided to go this route, publishing a book is a confusing and long journey, yet the instantpublishing online does the job; thus the reason for so many disappearing bookstores.
The strength of your article is that you clearly described the benefits of a hybrid book and contrasted it with an actual book to where I could understand why you would prefer a hybrid book.

The weakness of your article would be several grammatical errors, however I understood and followed what you were saying with no problem. I think your article could have had more bearing if you described one particular hybrid book.

The strengths of your Rough Draft are that you explained thoroughly an internet news community to where I did look it up, I had never heard of it before. The problem with the claim that this is "already the future of the internet" is that there are so many communities of information, it is sometimes difficult to decipher which carries the most accurate information. However, you could be very right, all the information we now receive is from sources that are not well known, and are put on by anyone, so that is accurate. You did a great job of striking my interest, so, as I said, I did look up your source and I will definitely look at it again for some information.

The only thing that I would offer as a grammatical change is to not begin a paragraph with the word "it". Everything was wonderful as far else as I could see. The entire assignment flowed very well and was interesting.

Your strength in your rough draft was that you kept my interest and I desired to look up the site that you cited. Everything flowed very well and I think this is an exciting way to jump off from a book into the technology aspect, as not everyone has a computer, but if they desire to go farther than a book, they have the option to do so. Our discussion boards are very similar, as gaining insight from each other aids in our learning and understanding. You taught me something with this, as I did not know it even existed, my mother still goes to book clubs at the local library, and this would definitely prove more convenient.
I did not find any weaknesses in your paper, as I stated previously, everything flowed very well and you held my interest.

The patch was very well done and simplified to the barebones of what was need, with some slight flare for aesthetics. It is apparent that this submission was created by someone with prior Max/MSP experience or has done a formidable amount of practice in such a small amount of time since class has begun. I did learn how I could have simplified my patch even further and how to add in a feature like the option to randomly choose an ASCII key code. Overall, this was A+ work for this assignment in my opinion.
The patch looked very colorful, and each part was explained nicely. There was even a little humor thrown into one explanation. Each part is split into three sections, and each part has its own color.

One thing I thought was really cool was the addition of a volume control that would let you control how loud or quiet the sounds were overall. Each sound has its own meter, so you can see how each loud or soft each sound was. I was more involved as a user since I could pick my own key number from a generator and control pretty much everything. However, the random number generator wouldn't give out a number, so I would have to type my own number to get it to run the sounds. The 'yes' sound was pleasant and not overbearing, and the 'no' sound made me cringe a little just because of what it actually was, but it was amusing though.

Technically, there was a lot going on "under the hood", but you couldn't see all the connections from the layout that was presented. Not a bad thing since it's much clearer that way. It's not until you unlock it could you poke around a little. I did learn how to use the volume controller since I thought that was nice touch to the whole thing. As mentioned earlier, the random number generator didn't work, so maybe double checking everything just to make sure everything works as it should. Other than that, it's a good patch.

Compared to what we initially created in class the aesthetic of this patch was definitely colorful and fun to look at. The overall feel was that it was engaging but the connections were hidden and obscured being able to know how this patch was made.

After getting over my initial confusion I enjoyed the humorous dynamic of the step by step instructions and enjoyed playing with it. The sounds were somewhat uncreative but succinct in their functionality.

Having an added volume control was a nice component to the overall interface. The overall approach was creative and fun although somehow seemingly simplistic. The color was a surprise and it was exciting to be involved in choosing a 'yes' key. The visual logic of the patch is straightforward, and text comments direct user action very clearly.
Using the patch is a humorous experience. The creator took the extremely simple premise of the assignment and made a clever single-serving application.

One significant technical problem is that the file was saved as .maxpat.txt, meaning it works only after the .txt extension is removed. It would have been much better if the file included was a max patch instead of a max patch interpreted as raw text. The use of several different outcomes from one piece of input data is a surprising technical innovation from which I feel I could learn something. The approach is very technically creative.

Simple and straight to the point, this patch was fun and easy to use. The primary sound was simple but slightly annoying (perhaps like a good 'no' sound should be. The surprise of the 'yay' when I found the yes key was extremely pleasing and the the fireworks certainly added a cool surprise.

Simple structure but effective, the added graphics were great but unexpected because they had not come up in class as an option within the creative process of this software. Seems like I am learning a lot about what the possibilities for more user friendly interface design. My only critic was that the buttons at the bottom could have been lined up more symmetrically.
It's wonderful. The sounds are entertaining and grasp the meaning of positivity and negativity.
The approach is perfect. I learned that UI and presentation mode in Max is very critical to developing a successful patch.

The header is very creative, presenting the challenge of attempting to locate the good key. It presents a nice, inviting title and lays out the challenge before you while still being minimal. The master sound button is a great idea, saving the viewer a little time by not having to scroll down and switch each individual sound button on. The logistic part of the patch, though, is much the same as we were presented in class, with a little extra fuddle and detracting clunkiness included.

Once the master sound button has been toggled to active the process becomes as simple as pressing different keyboard buttons until the right one has been pressed.; in this case it is "P". The sounds are clear in relaying to the user the information of the keyboard button, good or bad, but seem like stock audio samples that lack originality and are devoid of personality infusion on part of the programmer. The design is nice, but the sounds aren't entertaining to hear repeatedly, so after two/three times, I stopped the program.

The introduction of the header and master audio switch is a novel idea that is aesthetically pleasing and improves immensely the ease with which the viewer can control the program and use it correctly. The presence of the links between the different objects, necessary as they may be, slightly detract from the quality of the header and switch button. The actual working part of the program seems slightly clunky due to the zigzagging wires crossing through one another and the yes/no button signals. The organization of the patch elements and including more novel sounds will make the patch perfect.

This patch is very similar to that of the patch we went over in class. The good key and bad key branches are the same with two sfplay~ messages, two meters, two ezdac~ messages, minus the different sounds that correspond to each of them. I'm still a little unclear about how this patch works. Instead of just one "Good Key" there are two different "Good Keys" which play two different sound files of trains. The "Bad Keys" play the sound of 2 more different trains that alternate back and forth every time you hit a bad key. I find this to be rather confusing because all four of the train sounds are very similar to each other and it's hard to comprehend which keys are "good" and which keys are "bad." In total there are 5 different sound files present in this patch, which I kind of don't understand. I wasn't able to hear the fifth sound, which apparently was a bell that was also supposed to match with a specific key.

I appreciate the fact that Tom tried to do something different with his project and expand upon what was taught in class, but I do think he could have organized it better and chosen sounds that aren't extremely similar to each other. This patch is similar to that of the patch we went over in class with it having two branches, one for good key, one for bad key. Both sides have one sfplay~ message, a meter, and a ezdac~. The buttons are a lot bigger and in the center on top, there is a comment that welcomes the user to the patch. In the center of the branches, there is another comment that informs the user what to do.

While using this patch, I thought that the sounds were really entertaining to listen to. The difference between good key and bad key was very easy to determine and I thought that the sounds were really goofy and made me laugh. The big buttons helped out a lot in giving visual feedback to me and even the subtle changes of buttons changing color helped out a lot. My experience was a fun one, actually.

The experience is quite interesting, and wholly unique in its itself from the other four I have critiqued, in that the goal is to find the sequence of keyboard presses that relay the sentence, "Welcome, have a nice day." Many buttons say the welcome part and the rest of the sentence comes sequentially with the right presses; "A", "S", "D", "F" will elicit the words. It's a very novel and fun concept, the dullness of each word takes away from it a little, and the lifeless pronunciation detract.

The patch, like many of the others, is very basic in design, with the specific key numbers being listened for for each word and the files connecting to the speakers. The use of color coordination is a great idea in hindsight as it adds an extra element of organization to the patch and creates more visual appeal for the user/viewer.  2. Overall, I would give a 3/5 for completion and 5/5 for explanations and writing style.

For your report, you only partially completed the report. The Introduction needs to have both a problem statement and a description of the study, you should expound upon what you have. I do like your theory because you actually showed some of the mathematics of Newton's Method, but again you should explain the theory a bit more in depth, maybe go into more about the derivation because there is more to say. You have some evidence in your Study and Results, but try to explain all the things your code accomplished including the polynomial results and your own unique nonlinear equation's results. I think you could use the addition of more images, also make sure you create circles in your picture that match what the CP 1 Notes ask for. Once you have completed your report, you need to update your conclusion. I would also like to point out that you should have three codes for this computing project in your appendix, first is the polynomials given in the CP 1 Notes, second is the code for the two circles (which you have), and the third should be your own code with unique nonlinear equations. Don't be afraid to explore the computing project more!

You need to repeat the code from the notes as well as do your own exploration of a system that you come up if. I would focus more on Newton's Method than saying things about how it is a refresher on MATLAB and stuff like that.

I liked your report and really seemed like you knew what the project was all about. The conclusion should be longer than a sentence long, try going back to your introduction and reflect back on it. Tell weather or not the we were able to complete the purpose of this MATLAB project, then why or why not? Something along those lines, so it can help length that sections a little longer than a sentence. Other than that it was a good one :)

Your theory included all of the equations used in the project. In order to enhance you project think about adding more to your study and results. You definitely have all the evidence you need in your Study and Results for the polynomials, circles, and unique nonlinear equations, but I think the addition of some images would be very beneficial to your report. Don't forget about the ares of Depth and Significance, New Observations, and Scientific Competence. Once you have completed your report, you need to update your conclusion. I would also like to point out that you should have three codes for this computing project in your appendix, first is the polynomials given in the CP 1 Notes, second is the code for the two circles (which you have), and the third should be your own code with unique nonlinear equations. Don't be afraid to explore the computing project some more!

Hello,
 
 A few suggestions for you, that you may or may not want to use:
 
 -I would suggest using the grading criteria, and rubric as a guide. Include sections in your report (Introduction, Theory, Study and Results, Conclusion, and Appendix).

 -Give a brief introduction of what this report is going to detail, along with the theory behind everything (i.e. In the Theory section, you could include the equation of a general circle, and the derivative of the general circle, as that was used in the m-file).
 
 - While in your conclusion section, try to correlate what you discovered in the study and results section.
 
 p.s. Everything you wrote seemed to be correct (at least to me), you just need to use some section titles, and format a little bit. Add a few figures, and you should be set!

I think you need to read through your code verification again. Rememebr that these plots of the two intersection points are only estimates about the solution of the two intersections. After reading over your report, overall it looks great. There are a few elements in which you are missing (conclusion) section. The report is well organized and is reader friendly.

 In the study and results section, you give good step by step examples on what you did which makes this section look very professional. I would go back and put captions to all of your graphs stating what is going on or at least label them "Figure 1"...
 
 You lack a conclusion section. In this section your can tie in everything that you have done and how it relates to the class and how it can scientifically be applied to engineering. 
 
 In the Appendix section, I ran your code and it worked. 
 
 Overall, good job on the report and go back and modify what I have stated above so you don't miss out on points.

Even if most of the equations were already derived, copy and paste them into your report because if the reader had no previous knowledge as to what the computing project had to be about there would be a bit of confusion. Based off of the description that was written for this project, it was very clear for me to determine what the goal was. Due to how simple the goal was put, there was no possible way for me to misunderstand what the author was trying to accomplish.
 
 
 
 The way that the patch works is that it is activated by clicking on the toggle. The toggle then activates the two buttons and two metro objects which then activate the counters on each side. The counters are attached to two different sets of select objects which are numbered from 1 to 8 and 1 to 6, with 8 and 6 buttons on each side. These objects then obtain the information they need in order to play whatever note with the use of a message attached to each input and a combination of a kslider, a makenote object, and a noteout object. In case the notes are stuck, there is a flush message attached to each kslider in order to wipe the messages clean for the notes to start over.
 
 
 
 The author created a simple song with the use of 2 different set of notes. Their sequencer branched out into two different sides, one representing the left hand, the other representing the right hand. The left hand had chords, or played many notes at one time, while the right hand played single notes. After going over this patch, I thought that it was well made. The layout is very clear to understand and is very efficient at achieving its goal. I hardly see any fault with it.
 
 
 
 My only concrete suggestion is to possibly avoid having duplicate numbers in the chord messages.

 2. Add a way for the user to change time count and pitch value.

Description:
 
 "Untitled 2040" presents itself like a music box: a small, simple exterior concealing its complex and illusive inner workings. There is only one instruction, "JUST PRESS THE BUTTON!!!", and after doing so the viewer is presented with a simple and soft yet haunting melody. 
 
 
 
 Technical Analysis:
 
 On the top level, a button is pressed sending a bang to three sub-patches "short notes", "long notes" and "longgggg note". Each sub patch receives the bang to toggle the metronome and then begin a timed sequence through 53 steps. If a note is to be played, than the "select" function leads to a note number, which is sent to the "make a bleep" sub patch. There are 3 note lengths, 500, 1000 and 2000 ms. After the sequencer has completed, if there are no more inputs from the user, it loops.
 
 
 
 Conceptual analysis:
 
 I used the term "illusive" intentionally. At the beginning you are only presented with a really simple interface that betrays just enough of its inner workings to entice the user into imagining the clockwork structures that lie beneath the surface. But, if you try to pinpoint the exact location of the music, instead you get to see only hints of notes, disjointed between 3 sub patches. Breaking apart the work even further using the "make a bleep" patches contributes to it's overall ghostly feel. In the end, hearing the simple sine wave generators teases a person who tries to pick it apart. It's deceptively simple- yet it's hard to picture in the minds eye just how each cog in the machine rotates. 
 
 
 
 Improvement:
 
 If and only if the author is going for true simplicity would I suggest that this could be arranged differently. Sure, the author could combine each of the sub patches into one patch with only one metro and one select that lead to three sine wave generators- and doing so might make it easier for the user to know what's going on in the patch. But it would also ruin the experience a bit. Here, the illusion of simplicity adds to it an ethereal quality that would be lost if actual simplicity was achieved. Only after digging through all of the sub patches does the user understand the true meaning of the piece, and it's only instruction- like a pointillism, scrutinizing and dissecting this piece doesn't lead the viewer to more meaning, to view it you "JUST PRESS THE BUTTON!!!".

The project first opens up a small window with a button connected to 3 different sequencers (short, long, and longgggg) which play at the same time to produce the melody connected to the make_a_bleep patch. There are clear comments about the sequences and what she intended with the blank spaces.
 
 
 
 To make it easier to navigate there are four windows (the play button connecting the sequences, short, long and longgggg notes). She used an inlet to connect. It was a little redundant that she put in a button between the metro and counter, when she could just connect the metro directly to the counter. It was also redundant to put the button between the select and numbers when she could direct connect them, but I can understand that it would give a visual for where the counter is along the melody.
 
 
 
 I was confused at first seeing only the initial small window open. It did not play when I pressed the button. Only until I figured out to click the messages and turned on the sound in the sequencers, did it start playing. (Sorry for reading your comments last. Oops.) I had first played each of the sequencers by itself and then realized they were suppose to be played at the same time. It is very cute and pleasing to listen to. I really like the melody.

At first glance, the patch looks very simple, and it plays a nice melody. Things are packaged nicely into subpatches, according to note duration. The main patcher window has one button which, when pressed, toggles the subpatches to create the melody. The concept was very nice and enjoyable. Being standard MIDI notes, it does begin to grate on your ears after a few times through. Right offhand, I can't think of anything that would have made it better.

There is nothing interesting about the patch itself, but I was excited to hear the song since I am familiar with "Funky Town". But honestly, even though I had the songs melody in my head before I played the patch, I had trouble recognizing it when the patch played. There are pauses in the actual song that were not in the patch. It would have been much more recognizable if the pauses had been incorporated. The patch worked flawlessly. Adding the pauses would be the only thing I'd suggest.

This sequencer was easy to understand and very enjoyable to listen to. The sequencer is activated through the button objects, which played the tune of funky town. The design of the sequencer was familiar, yet still held original characteristics in functionality. I would suggest to add more background notes by adding another sequencer branch for the music to feel more "whole" in composition.

One toggle, one metronome, one counter, ten buttons, ten notes, a beep and a speaker. Works well and fulfills the basic requirements of this project. Also uses well known tune that is easily recognizable. This is truly a basic sequencer in the utmost sense of the word, this concept could really have used additional development. Either a longer loop, additional parts, graphics or even a volume control could have added additional dimensions that would have taken this piece to the next level. Slightly disappointed that there was not more to it. Maybe this person is struggling with the program or musical composition is not their thing. Hope to see something a little more developed in the future.

This patch meets all the expectations for the assignment. The organization is clear, although there is no commenting. It runs exactly as the in-class demo did: toggle, to metronome, to counter set with 1 and 10 as parameters, to the selector with the parameters identified explicitly, to the numerical values assigned each numeric parameter, to a number box reporting which line of the parameters is active, to the sound generator subpatch, and finally to the speaker. As far as feel, it was sort of lackluster. It was the minimum required for the assignment and nothing more. This is nitpicky, but I would have sped up the metronome tempo to match the song.

Initially the patch looks great, it looks like it is a pretty simple concept but still has a very cool technical look to it. It also worked perfectly upon trying it out. It was neat and the jingle it played was pretty cool. The only thing that you could have done that might have been cool is throw in the synthesizer keyboard for added visual effect.

I really like this layout, it's nicely organized into four different sections. The midi track, and then three "make a bleep" sounds running under their own separate counters. 
 
 
 
 This patch works by turning it on with the toggle, which triggers the wav file that contains the drum beat, and the three bleep pieces that offer melody to the beat. 
 
 
 
 I think it's awesome that you went beyond having a patch that only contains "bleeps," and actually incorporated a bet into it. This made the whole thing feel much more authentic, and just overall more musical. It kind of sounded like old video game midi sounds with a drum beat under it!
 
 
 
 I'm not totally sure if the wav file is perfectly in time with the bleep sounds, but it doesn't sound too off.

By toggling the button, the patch begins an avant-garde sounding song with a percussion track. Each select option connected to several different keys, which made the whole thing sound spacey and cleverly ambient. There was also a wav file that played along with the rest of them. I really enjoyed the cool song that it played. That being said, I'm not sure it sounds exactly how the author intended. One select option had 5 beats, which contrasted with the 8 beat selector on one and the 7 beat selector on the other. If intentional, it was a cool effect! I would suggest possibly stating on the description the kind of sound you wanted to portray instead of just saying it may not work (confidence is key)! Also, the drum track continued playing even after toggling it off. Overall though, it worked very well!
I felt like it could have been the background music for an old nintendo game, I liked that. I would have cleaned up/organized the patch a little more but overall it was good.

The patch was well organized, I could tell what was going on. It works perfectly fine. It didn't really make me feel anything, it just made me think of aliens. I would improve this patch by adding one more note to each sound. It sounds like it's one note too short.

Opens a window with a large toggle button that triggers three sequences and a wav rhythm to go along it. (There is a random button floating in the third sequence. Haha.) It goes to the make_a_bleep patch to play.
 
 
 
 It was a little redundant that there is a button between the metro and counter, when it could just connect the metro directly to the counter. It was also redundant to put the button between the select and numbers when it could directly be connected, but I can understand that it would give a visual for where the counter is along the melody. The open SongforMaxPatch.wav is opened twice in the sequence by the big toggle and the first sequence pattern (redundant).
 
 
 
 It seems to just be a random rhythm sequence, but it's fun and interesting to listen to. I was initially confused when I stopped it from playing and I still heard a rhythm. The wav file could have been shorter, so when the toggle is off, the music will stop more immediately.

Opens up a simple sequence and has the user presses the toggle to play "Mary Had a Little Lamb." Connects to p make_a_bleep.
 
 
 
 It was a little redundant that there is a button between the metro and counter, when it could just connect the metro directly to the counter. It was also redundant to put the button between the select and numbers when it could directly be connected, but I can understand that it would give a visual for where the counter is along the melody.
 
 
 
 It was interesting that the sequence connects several of the select bang points to single points (each time to sequence/melody hits F#, the point is connected to a single 66). While this isn't as easy to see the rests or the individual points when the melody hits F#, it makes it more condensed.

Description:
 
 This patch plays the tune "Mary Had a Little Lamb".
 
 
 
 Technical Analysis: 
 
 When a bang is received, it begins a metro counting every 500 ms. The counter then cycles through all 32 steps in the sequence. If a note is to be played, the select function sends a bang to a message containing the note value to the "make a bleep" patch which produces the sine wave.
 
 
 
 Conceptual Analysis:
 
 "Untitled 2055" is successful in meeting all of the requirements of the assignment. The tune it produces is recognizable and everything works as described. It is the ultimate expression of utility and adequacy. 
 
 
 
 Suggestion:
 
 The only thing that I would suggest is getting rid of the number that's connected to the metro object. The number selects the time in-between each count by the metro, but the metro object already has "500" as the time. So, unless the author wanted the user to change the tempo of the piece, the number can be removed.

You did it! The patch works, it's neat, and it's obviously Mary Had a Little Lamb. By all accounts you've completed the assignment parameters nicely. 
 
 
 
 If you were to go above and beyond I wonder what you may have challenged yourself to do. I would also add a comment to the toggle box out of curtesy to let a new user of your patch know more directly how to activate it. Overall, well done in completing the assignment. Now to see where your creativity comes in when given more time or a more interesting project...

Your sequencer was clean and seemed to worked well. I feel like your sequencer worked well considering the level of work it took to make it. I feel like you made successful easy sequencer (nothing wrong with that) that worked correctly. One suggestion would be to go a little out of the box considering this was one of the examples he showed. But overall, good work.

This one was a little bit confusing to me because I couldn't hear what part of Smells Like Teen Spirit this was from, but you did a good job and used a lot of notes. Also the instructions were very clear.

This patch loks like another take on playing the piano via a metronome such as was taught in class. What makes this interesting and technically different is the addition of the saw~ tool which antialiases the music giving it a darker electronic feel to the classic piano notes. It creates an aspect of darkness and terror, like something in an electronica haunted house. My suggestion would be to set the volume initially low and allow others to ramp it up because it blasted out my speakers on accident the first time I used it, although this was partially my fault for keeping the speakers up too high for the last patch.

The patch sends a metro to a subpatch containing two small sequencers attached to MIDI outputs and back out to an sfplay~. The sounds are cacophonous and a little grating, but not in a way that hurts the ears. It's irritating but not painful. Spot on with the stated intention.

I read the description and saw it would be irritating which I was not very happy with but it was still a very solid piece. I love the setup and the help it provides, I just dislike the sound itself.

The sequencer does play a recognizable tune of Happy Birthday. It achieves this by the use of many selects hooked to numbers for bleeps. The overall concept was there, but because the timing system was rigid to only having beats in time with the single metronome some of the bleeps were out of time for the song. The note timing could be changed by implementing a delay object between the select and the message for the note. By doing this, you could "hold" the bang for however long you want, only sending the message after the specified amount of time.

The patch looks great, I can see that the creator has made both a melody and a harmony. Still, I'm glad that they had both the melody and the harmony instead of just the melody like the other patches I've looked at. Just fix the issue with the chords. Based off of the description for this project, it was clear to me that this patch was built to play a sequence of notes that make up a melody. There is no possible way for me to misunderstand what the author is trying to accomplish.
 
 
 
 The way that this patch works is that it is activated by clicking on the top toggle. The toggle then activates the two multicolored buttons and two metro objects which then activate the counters, which range from 1-24 on each side. The counters are attached to two different sets of select objects which are numbered from 1-24, which are attached to different colored buttons. The buttons then are attached to a hidden and background checkbox, which can be selected to hide the buttons. These objects then obtain the information they need in order to play whatever note with the use of a numbered message attached to each input. The number is attached to each input, and is then attached to a number object, which shows what number it received. This object is then attached to a makenote object and a noteout object that plays different notes based off of the individual number message it receives, it makes a sound. 
 
 
 
 The author managed to create a simple sequencer that played random notes that made up a melody. The multicolored buttons served as a good visual feedback and was considerably different than the original sequencer we learned about. Also the checkboxes that hid the buttons that were attached to the inputs for the select objects was also something that I thought was very interesting.
 
 
 
 My only concrete suggestion would be to possibly omit the number object that is directly attached to the metro object. I feel as though it does not really serve a purpose being there.
