Right off the bat I could tell this patch a lot of thought put into it. It a colorful, yet simplistic and organized interface that was fairly simple to use. I was glad the author designed a presentation mode interface, because I think if I were faced with the raw patch I would have been utterly confused. That said, a few parts of the raw patch(non presentation) were a bit disorganized, but I think that might be because they were the visual components. The patch was an elaborate 16 beat sequencer that played a series of notes defined by the user by clicking and unclicking boxes. I was a bit confused on how to work the patch at first, but eventually I figured it out, maybe a little blurb about directions in the future? In addition, to that suggestion, when opening and playing the patch, I couldn't hear the sounds being played until increasing the volume almost all the way to the top/right of the slider. This was misleading because the volume appeared to be half-way up.

The striking red outline of all the components is the first thing that catches my eye upon opening the patch; it sets the mood quite well for the song that is being played. The sequencers have been arranged side by side with all the connections twisting about each other as they go into the message boxes. The metronome command and toggle play both, producing the easily recognizable melody from the grand composition. It is a stirring composition, and hearing it in bleep/bloop format is quite interesting, as if it was an NES game that the track had been taken from. My only suggestion of improvement would be playing with the piano note synthesizer to put it into classical format.

The patch is a two-part sequencer designed to play a song with polyphony. It uses the methods taught in class, with two "make a bleep" objects for polyphony/harmony. The author creatively interpreted sheet music according to Max methods to try and represent a performance of a popular song, and the result is fun to play with. In the description, the author expresses confusion as to how to represent eighth notes, which could have been achieved with relative ease by adding more steps to the counter (and consequently the sequencer), increasing the metronome tempo, and adding rests. Moreover, a few added steps/rests at the end of the sequence would have matched the represented tune to a full bar of the song. In general, this project is successful.

I really enjoyed this work, it was simple to understand as soon as I opened it, the colors were please to the eye and I knew exactly where to go first. As soon as I hit the toggle I was able to recognize the song. I liked how you did one metro in half time to even up the chords along with the lead part. Overall very good representation of this piece through "bleeps!"

The overall look of this sequencer is very similar to the ones we did in class although there is another component which acts as a left hand and a right hand. I like the song it makes me happy and is something I can listen to on repeat cause its fun. The song is well done and flows smoothly. I think it needs more creative components to it such as visuals or something the user can interact with to make it more fun but over all it was good work.

A really cool song! I liked how the left hand and the right hand were different tempos. The patch is really simple to use, all you have to do is click a button. After listening to the song for about a minute, I felt relaxed. I liked the set up of the patch because it looks a lot like mine.

Toggle connected to two metronomes, one set at half speed to the other. Splits into 18 and 30 channels of notes, left hand playing chords and right hand playing melody. Well crafted and nice use of chords, simple design, effective. I like the tune, it has an interesting melody. Concept is basic but well done. May have been interesting to show speaker or additional hidden elements to create a more interesting visual appearance. Volume controls could have also been added to isolate the different parts.

The patch has a fairly simple layout; there is a main toggle that activates the "right hand" and "left hand." I don't know if it's just how I'm hearing it after a few times through, but it seems to get a little out of sync as it goes on. I enjoy the concept, and it sounds nice overall. Maybe with a little more time, the note duration and synchronizing could be perfected.

Upon opening the patch I can see that it's very well laid out and clean as to give the viewer an understanding of how everything in ran and what it's being connected to. The set up to the patch it pretty straight forward in terms of the technical aspect of it. There are two parts, one for the left hand, and the other for the right hand. There are two separate tempo meters to give it a more of a feel that a pianist is playing the song. It's all done by a click of the switch, and the smoothing tones of the Jontron theme are playing. It's also fairly accurate too. I can think of nothing that the creator can do better on since everything was laid out and everything made sense.
It was a well designed patch, and it sounded very much like the song provided.

Your patch is nice and consolidated, but I found it slightly confusing. I couldnt tell how the first two gates changed things. I enjoyed the music you made though. The comment boxes helped, though a few more that told me what did what could help.

I enjoyed the blending of samples and midi. I found it to be a pleasant melody in general, and how the patch worked was pretty easy to figure out. GIving the user the option to raise levels on the individual samples was pretty cool. Conceptually, you did a pretty good job of blending melody and rhythm into an interactive experience. My only suggestion would be to raise the bpm a wee bit.
I like the interaction with the patch, how I was able to switch things and control the volume of the different sounds.

The patch is a complicated sequencer designed to play different concordant sequences. It achieves this using switches and several sequencers designed using the in-class method. Conceptually, it achieves much of the beauty and spontaneity it intends to; I'm surprised to hear the different sounds. Still, the volume sliders are a bit unnecessary and erratic, as it's not immediately obvious why not all of the sounds are audible. Additionally, the patch could be improved with more sounds or greater complexity, such that clicking one of the switches would have an immediately obvious effect.

So far this one takes the cake. The interface was easy to use and intuitive. There were a number of objects in this patch that I didn't recognize, but the signal flow looks essentially the same as what we saw in class. Since this was a dynamic sequencer rather than a song loop I'm not sure if I have the know-how to say with any certainty how this patch works. It was fun to mess around with, and ultimately generated some interesting sounds. I would have liked there to be more comments. There were some number boxes whose function was ambiguous, amongst other things and instructions would have helped.

When opening the patch, it was pretty big and had to scroll down to get the sound going. Technically, it worked well and didn't run into much problems upon starting the song. As the creator described, the song is original, but it is inspired by daft punk and it felt alright to use. A suggest I have to put down is to keep decrease the size of the make a bleep command and the sound toggle.

So, a toggle sends a 1 to two different metros which then send bangs to three separate sets of counters/selects. The sounds are very spaceship-esque (very sci-fi), the track with the metro (set at just 3 miliseconds!) just starts sounding gnawing. I realize they were going for the three sounds to be together, but it just sounds droning. However, I do like the two other parts together. If I had done this one, I would have just used two metro/counter/select pairs, and just had one select output go to two different make_a_beeps. Also, I slowed down the metronome on the short one and the whole thing became more musically interesting.

Your patch was relatively neat and straightforward. The original creation was pleasing to listen to so well done with your creative freedom for this project. I hope your brain wasn't hurt too much in your previous efforts in changing the sound file. I wonder what you were trying to do in more technical terms so that perhaps in the future you could complete what you originally intended. 
 
 
 
 In any case, good job! You did the class assignment with some added creativity.

This patch has three sequencers in it rather than the usually expected two. The third one adds an extra element of sound by having all the tones continuously going off at the same time to produce a constant undertone. The other two cycle through an eight-note sequencer to produce a sci-fi like melody that plays on repeat. It sound great with the undertone going, but can feel rather stock/cliche after the first few times cycling through. My suggestion for improvement would be either experimenting with tempo or adding in effects that can alter/distort the individual notes in a manner that the sound can change and keep pleasing listeners.

The patch looked similar to what I originally wanted to do, which was cool. I can't imagine how long it took them to develop that funky song. The overall layout of the patch was nice, it wasn't too organized but that is also a personal preference, On a technical note, the patch functions just right, all the numbers that relate to the make a note sub patch are really awesome and well thought out. Conceptually, I had a lot of fun playing with this patch and listening to the music that they created. I honestly enjoyed the strange Star Trek, Power Ranger-y song.

I enjoyed that the sequencer was exactly what was asked for; simple. I also liked the use of midi notes. I also ran into the issue of not being able to do multiple "hands" well. So again, I have other versions of my patch, but I still submitted what was the most simplistic to ensure it would work correctly.

The patch has a nice layout and they didn't choose to have the sound come from a second patch. By routing the select to the same notes they didn't need to repeat the sounds in the beginning, but they did repeat notes later in the song. It worked as planned.

The design of the sequencer reflected that of what was constructed in class, which is perfectly fine. The sequencer was activated through the button object, which played the tune of Fur Elise. Overall, a good attempt at creating a sequencer. The music was enjoyable to listen to and the design of the sequencer was familiar enough that did not leave me confused or overwhelmed. The creator of the sequencer had trouble with additions to the notes, which can be attributed to the lack of time available in constructing our sequencers. If the user had more time, his/her work could have been more complete. Therefore, the only suggestion I could make was the addition of a sequencer branch to make the composition sound more fuller. Overall, nice job!

I liked the overall layout of the patch, it didn't feel to clustered or jam-packed. Technical speaking, I also enjoyed the patch. There were somethings in the patch that I didn't even know were possible with MAX. For example, how they just connected the first two numbers four times into the select object, thus creating the repetition in the first part. The overall conceptual idea of the patch was pretty simple but how they pulled it off made the patch truly enjoyable for the user.

This patch takes the piano and plays the beginning of Beethoven's 5. The author does a similar job of hooking up a metronome, select command, although changes and runs the Piano in a slightly different way in the code than previous authors did. I like the feeling of quaintness of the patch and it made me feel classical with the music selection. The author could have added saw~ or extra buttons to make the experience different or more interactive.

This is a very complex sequencer hidden behind a giant button playing "Comptine d'Un Autre Ã‰tÃ©- Die fabelhafte Welt der AmÃ©lie." I understand the flow of it for the most part, but I get a little lost in it since it is complex. I wish I could offer more critique.
 
 
 
 It was a little redundant that there is a button between the metro and counter, when it could just connect the metro directly to the counter. It was also redundant to put the button between the select and numbers when it could directly be connected, but I can understand that it would give a visual for where the counter is along the melody.
 
 
 
 This is amazing. I love it. I'm saving it for future reference because this is too cool. It was very user friendly with the large button. I didn't realize how much would be hiding behind it. Great work.

This patch is a simple button that plays a song, with bass and melody. It seems complex yet is presented in an easy-to-use way. Technically, the patch works just as a normal sequencer, using a metro to play the base and another metro to control the melody. There are many more metros and counters within each to control the timing of everything. The author created a nice-sounding song without using a complicated method, so I can still understand how it works with my basic Max knowledge. I would suggest making it easier to access the sub-patches for critique, and commenting the work.

This is a beautiful patch, that really could have done well with presentation mode. The interface was simple but interesting and I appreciated the few notes, as well as the organized subpatches. The sound had a lovely music box quality, and there was even layers of planning enough to have it come to a natural stop. Well done. I would have loved more comments in the subpatches, as I didn't catch exactly what was going on at first. Well done.

Upon opening the Patch, I was quite amazed for ow simple it looked at first. The patch works great despite how simple it looks, at the press of a single button it's all smooth sailing from here. The creator made a simple song of sorts and it felt amazing that something could look so simple play such a greatly composed song. I got nothing to say on technical feedback but I'm really satisfied with the patch despite the loud beep at the beginning.

The design is really great, the colors are pleasant and I could just stare at it for hours. The technical parts were hidden and didn't distract from the overall look. I love this patch, it makes me want to step up my game and try a little harder.

The song is nice, not sure what it was or if you made it, but good job. Its easy to follow with the top down structure. Including the piano as a visual aid is also a good idea. The song kind of made me feel like I was in a western saloon. A suggestion might be to maybe soften up some of the hard notes or maybe extend them to flow better.

This is the first patch I've seen that doesn't use the 'make a bleep' sub patch and I felt like hearing the piano sound separated this one quite a bit from others. Also, multiple notes are being played a once which is very cool. This is the most impressive technical part. Using commas to keep all of the note numbers in one message box so that they will be played together. I felt joyful listening to the light carefree music and also watching the patch work efficiently. Maybe there is a way to condense all of the numbers so that it doesn't look as cluttered.

Upon opening the patch I was initially put off by the organization. There seemed to be numbers and connection strings everywhere and it overwhelmed me a little. However, after I pressed play I was really, really impressed with the composition he/she had created. I had never heard this piece before and although it was a pretty basic piano track, this person implemented the use of chords in addition to individual notes. I'm not sure I would even know how to do that myself yet, so I applaud the creator of this patch. I really don't think I would suggest doing anything differently except maybe organizing it in a way that is more user friendly - making it easier to comprehend the construction to really understand what exactly is going on.

The patch uses make a note. It works great and plays notes and chords. The sound produced is more like a real piano which was very nice to hear. It uses a counter, from 1 to 48, to sequence the notes to be played. It definitely made me sayWOW! It also shows that a lot of care and work went into the program. I am glad the connection chords are routed behind the note numbers, and I can see how this got very complicated. The only suggestion I could make would be to tame the spaghetti chords in the back, but that is a personal preference. In the old days, we called some codespaghetti code when the paths weren't clear. One way to do that would be to break up the work into multiple select statements working off of the same counter. That would break it up into more manageable pieces, or bars, and make it easier to maintain or modify. However that said, I know many artists who like the organic nature of exposed wires and find them beautiful.

There's a ton of notes here making the appearance look somewhat messy, but it still follows the same design shown to us in class, and the key buttons to make it run smoothly are easily identifiable. 
 
 
 
 This patch goes starts with the toggle, goes through the metro,and then goes on to select the desired notes after counting through 48 beats. A midi key board is included at the bottom to give a visual representation of what notes are being selected. 
 
 
 
 I like that you chose a classical piece and included piano sounds over the bleep sounds. The piano sounds just add to the authenticity since you've chosen a classical piano piece in the first place.
 
 
 
 It works nicely, and sounds good. There's not much I can say to add due to the fact that this a piano piece, and you've constructed this patch to do exactly that, play the piano piece. Well done!

It looked interesting enough to look at and i was looking forward to use it but the sound was not playing for me, i turned on the speakers in the program and i made sure all sound files were properly placed in the same folder as the project so it would work.

Right off the bat this patch looks super interesting. I see three sound boxes so I immediately assume that whatever it will produce will be pretty elaborate. Upon 'dropping the beat' I was pretty impressed with what you created, it was cool to see how much you could really do with this assignment.

I really enjoyed this patch, it was different and it mades me wish I tried harder. I didn't recognize some of the commands and I used the help to figure them out. I overall really liked what they did.

This is a good patch and easy to follow based on the layout. The volume sliders made this patch enjoyable. being able to make the bass overpower the rest (as well as my computer speakers) was a bit of fun. Changing the volume was a nice touch. To improve you could add different types of imported bass, just as a little more variety.

The work is visually appealing and makes you want to engage with the patch. I really like that you pushed yourself even though you said you did not have the knowledge of music. Creating a counter up to 35 to incorporate the first two parts of Fur Elise was a way of definitely pushing yourself and that fact that it is clearly recognizable is great. I would have never known that you did not have a greater understanding of music by this patch. A simple toggle button engages the metro with a counter measure of 1-35, which feeds into your output to engage the specific keys to the Fur Elise song. I don't really know any suggestions that I could make because I think it is great peice. Maybe another layer could be adding color to the piece.

Great job is getting the assignment done and making a neat max patch. Considering you do not have a music training background your efforts to transcribe the song are commendable. The sequencer is easily recognizable as the beginning to Fur Elise. 
 
 
 
 If you were given more time I'm sure you'd practice the nuances of rests by placing in "blank" select slots with the proper metro designations, but this easily becomes complicated with a piece of Beethoven. 
 
 
 
 Well done!

I had to turn the sound on. But after that it worked. I enjoyed the lay out. I felt it was easy to follow and how the project was achieved. I could easily replicate. I feel this is an important feature of any project such as this; Can I see how you did what you did so I could make it.

The sequencer was simple in design and easy to control. The song "Fur Elise" was played when the sequencer was activated through the button objects. Due to the lack of knowledge with music, the creator did mention that he received a majority of help through Youtube and was able to construct the sequencer to play the same tune. The sequencer was not complicated, which is great for those who get overwhelmed easily. The only suggestion I could make was to at least attempt to create a different song...maybe an original song in order to better understand music. It is difficult to understand music when you have had no prior experience with music composition, but time and practice can change that difficulty level to a simpler one. Overall, it was a good sequencer and song, but I would have liked to see more originality in the design and music design.
Very simple patch. I like the choice of music selection also.

First off this patch is way to big this does not fit my screen! You could of made the buttons a bit smaller. next is the colorful scheme which I enjoy it makes the patch more intriguing. The sound however is very subliminal. I feel like I am listening to some sort of art installation and all you are missing is a video display. Overall its a nice patch just needed to be a bit smaller no need for those excessively big buttons.

Very technical appearance, with big pretty buttons all over the place and wires going in every direction. Still I don't feel it looks messy at all, since the toggle object stands tall in purple at the top of the patch.
 
 
 
 There seems to be many different metro-counter-select-make a bleep arrangements going on simultaneously with the wav files you have included with the "sfplay."
 
 
 
 You've obviously included some sort of message behind this piece, with the random "life doesn't give a f**k's" and robotic woman speaking over the bleep sounds. The message may be obscure, but with that comes a certain level of curiosity that makes this patch compelling. 
 
 
 
 I don't know if there's much to change here. The layout may be complex, but getting the patch to run is very simple and that's all that really matters.
Although confusing to work and hear, the patch was aesthetically pleasing. And the sounds seemed to mesh well together.

Awesome. First of all it looks great. Secondly your samples are creative and I find the cheerful bloopy almost childlike melody over the raw hard samples a nice contrast. One thing I would think be cool, although possibly contrary to your artistic image would be to have the melody and samples playing in time to create a more music scene overall.

WOW, was definitely my first impression. The intricacies of the piece are incredible and the incorporation of the various size component and colors; green, yellow and red give it a level of initial visual intensity that is definitely engaging. Once you turn on the piece you realize the greater level of artistic flow. For me, this piece invoked a strong feeling angst, listen to the layering of the words takes me to the challenges I have faced in life when I felt someone how I was entitled to a better outcome. I really do not have any suggestions for improvement. This piece was very thought invoking, more so than any piece I have seen......great artistic expression!

This patch had be laughing so hard, it was done so well and it could almost replace 2Chainz in that song. It had a simple feel to it, with a normal toggle just like the example from class. The use of the "open" feature was cool because you were able to use samples to create a drum beat, sounding just like the real thing, and the vocal samples that you could include were just the icing on the cake. Love it!

The patch when I first opened it was pretty cool. I enjoyed that it wasn't just a basic looking Max patch but rather a fun bright patch. Just from looking at the patch, you can identify that the creator spent a good about of time on creating it. On a technical stand point, it functioned perfectly once I loaded the additional sounds on to my computer. The song was completely recognizable and was super fun to play around with. I enjoyed how to the creator made it fun to listen to and how it was easily recognizable. I really liked this patch.

Very nice Patch 2Chainz! I can tell you are a fan of his music. I very much enjoy this piece, its very different from other patches. The beat is almost exactly like the song. Very cool and creative patch I really enjoy this. You could of change the button color scheme like gold and red but thats my opinion.

Toggle connected to two metronomes, one connected to melody while the other is playing drum sample. Additional buttons allow user to play additional samples. Interactive and includes graphics. Works well and fun to play with, clearly illustrated. This was my favorite as it combined samples and interactive graphic components. Simple but easy to use and shows musical talent based on compositional elements. Could have added other samples and made the loop longer. Maybe some additional graphics?

There is a nice combination of color in this, purple and yellow, but the rest of the patch has been laid out in typical fashion, a good thing to do. The interesting aspect of this patch is the inclusion of the open command and sfplay~ command in loading vocal sound files in time with the notes being played on the other sequencer, and the command of being able to play sound files on command by pressing one of the two additional buttons included. While the technical aspects are very interesting I do not care much for the actual sound/music because I am not a fan of rap. I think that working the button commands into the sequencers by turning it into more of a sound mixing board where audio can be played on demand in a way that alters the flow of the track would be awesome.

Super cool and very complicated code under a super clean presentation mode. There are four parts. The main part plays constantly at the default volume. The other three parts of the music are inaudible at first but are controlled by sliders that made this patch both interactive and fun to use. This was an extremely well thought out patch. I played with it for too long because now the tune is stuck in my head! 
 
 At first I couldn't get the fourth part to play, but this was a minor issue. I went back to the download file and there was a folder in a folder. In order to hear the fourth part I had to put all the sound bites from both folders onto my desktop. A small operation but well worth the effort, because the patch was so cool?

Very nice yet complicated visually. The patch was pretty complex visually but worked flawlessly. The instructions served to get me started and were much appreciated. The patch was organized neatly and was visually pleasing. I really enjoyed the melodies as well. The only thing is maybe one comment to tell me exactly where the volume bars are, since I am a noob it took me a second or two to figure it out. Great patch!!! Thank you

This is so nice. Firstly, I thought it was very interesting that the author decided to use sound files to play each note instead of using the MIDI messages to trigger an instrument. Regardless, the program turned out wonderfully. I liked the presentation mode and how each beat triggered a "light" which was really just a button. The program runs by using a metro object that sends bangs to various messages that contain MIDI number values. It seems as if the author correlated the number values with .aif files of each of the notes she/he needed. I would suggest that it may have more functionality to use a midi instrument since that would give the sequencer more usability in a music setting. Regardless, it is a wonderful program.

This patch has three main blocks of components, all pretty large. The left-most part was actually cut off and had to be moved so I could see all of the parts, which could have just been an issue with my screen resolution being smaller than the one in which the patch was made. It seems pretty intricate, though, and probably took a lot of work to get right. It works by pressing the large square button that has a few "press to start" messages surrounding it, which triggers three different metronomes to start and play beats through counters and select objects. I really enjoyed this patch. I've always been a (very) casual LoZ fan, and very much enjoyed all of the music/songs that are part of the games. The song sounded really nice, very calming and serene. To improve the work, my main suggestion would be to better organize the patch. All of the metronomes had the same interval, so only one was really needed, and one "make a bleep" probably would have been enough, however I didn't mess with it much to see if there were multiple copies for a reason.

I enjoyed seeing the songs people picked to play. The noise of the synth matches the tonality of the video game. So I enjoyed that link. (Pun intended) 
 
 I felt it was cumbersome in parts, or the spacing of the notes was off. 
 
 However, overall, this was a very good project.

The patch sequences the song starting with a single toggle which is hooked to three identical metros. From there each metro is hooked to a counter with the arguments 1 48. Then through three selects the patch sends note numbers to make a bleep objects. I'm not completely familiar with the tune, but it felt as though there were some awkwardly long pauses in the melody. Also this patch could have been achieved with 2 fewer metros and counters. Rather than make identical objects, consider making a single master time keeper, and then use send and receive to pass the information to different sections of the patch. Overall it would be cleaner and perform better as the complexity of works increases.

Initially I opened it partially expecting what I would get out of the patch in the end. As if the title didn't give it away. it looked pretty good when I opened it, maybe it could have been organized better, but that is just my opinion. There were also good comments to help the user touch what they should, and not touch what they shouldn't. When I started the patch, my suspicions were verified. It was indeed the song of storms. It made me feel good. I especially enjoyed the fact that I could change the speed of it. Overall, It was wonderful. The only suggestions I can make are to set bounds on adjustable number objects. Other than that, Awesome job! Legend of Zelda is awesome!
Great and simple sequencer. Polyphonic and great choice in music. I don't know how it can be improved upon. I'm just enjoying the song as I write this review.

Sonically, this is the most interesting piece so far, as it uses more than just the built-in MIDI tones. The patch looks a little busy, but with everything that was included, it has to be. The whole process is activated with a single toggle, which runs various subpatches playing the notes. The description given for the concept is a little confusing, but I like the outcome. I think this may have worked out better if I understood the goal of the author, so maybe just making things a little more clear.

The patch looks kinda complicated since it has many objects we didn't learn about. The sound of the patch was nice to listen to and sounded very futuristic. I liked it very much because it had a "whoosh" sound at the end and I thought it was cool and wondered how to make that. The patch worked correctly, it played a song over and over again. There were symbols at the top of the patch that I wasn't quite sure what they did at first but then I understood that they were two parts of the song and that it combined them together. I thought it was really neat way of doing that. Maybe for improvement make the patch a little less cleaner, ti seems very spread out.

The patch looks a bit complex, yet the buttons used to control the patch are simple. It seems to work through subpatches with their own metros and counters that cause notes to play. There are two different 'songs' that are playing, which can both be triggered off and on. Technically it seems that it works well but could have been organized better. Conceptually, the patch feels unique yet not something that I personally find interesting or nice to listen to. I believe someone more interested in music would find this patch to be interesting. I suggest making the patch more organized or commenting with the purpose for various things.

The patch was clean and slightly complex at the same time which is good. The song piece, which was an original I'm guessing, was pretty cool. I was a little confused by the number options (0, 1, -1, 0) because they didn't do anything as far as I could tell. Overall it was a pretty clean and cool patch.

Super dope little loop you got there. The interface was very simple to understand and use. I like the reversed beat hit and the neat melody including bass tones. I can actually listen to the loop for a while. My only suggestion would be perhaps accentuating the simplicity of the patch's function by bringing it into presentation mode and making the interface even simpler.

The organization of the patch could be a little better but overal you did a very good job. I enjoyed the sounds it brought me to a feeling of happiness. Maybe adding a filter would go a long way with this patch.

This, as soon as I opened it was very interesting and cool. I like how you explained everything that went into the design of the patch. And the actual song that played was very good and well put together. I'm actually interested how you did quite a few things.. All in all the sequencer turned out sick and I think you've got this one down.

The complexity of the piece is extremely impressive. This is far beyond anything I could fathom creating in max. the intricacies of the piece are incredible and the incorporation of the 560 individual notes was outstanding. The fact that you spent the extra time trying to understand the programming aspect and simplifying the patch by adding the simple text file line by line made for a much easier user experience. I also felt like you were trying to educate the user by adding the text boxes. I really appreciate this, because it gave clarity to parts of your patch that were over my head. Once you turn on the piece you realize the greater level of artistic flow. I really do not have any suggestions for improvement. It might be fun to add a greater visual component by adding more color to the piece.

The patch is very well organized for how intense it is. This is a really cool sequencer that plays Bach's Solfeggieto in numeric values. There are several text files that call the numbers because there are so many which makes the patch very organized. I am amazed that you had the time for this. The song is fantastic and seems really complicated and time consuming to go through all the sheet music, unless you put it through a translator. The only thing I think would be really cool is if you made some visual components with it so it looked cool as well as sounded really cool. Overall, Good job!

The patch looks decently clean and simple for the complexity it involves. My issue was that I wasn't for whatever reason able to hear anything. The patch does include comments which are nice and seems to stray from the example made in class which is good because it shows other ways of achieving things. I just wish I could've heard it.
The visual was very colorful i enjoyed looking at it. The melody was excellent and i enjoy classical music as well. I believe this person did the job and did it right.

The patch is colorful and pleasing to the eye, simple and easy connections. The music plays when the toggle is switched on and the same set of eight notes plays twice before one (or two) of the notes change higher or lower by a single note. The process is repeated for the different colors and is a continuous loop. I really like how the color changes for the buttons as their sound plays so that I knew exactly where I was. I was excited and tried to guess which note would change next in the sequence and try to figure out if more than one changed. For improvement I think it would be neat to add an accompaniment.
Looks simple and easy to use. The colors add some fun to the project and I like how the chords change.

The patch looks very nice, with the colors adding more interest instead of just the regular grey. It works really well. I like how you figured out how to change the notes without making it look confusing. I feel like a lot of work was put into this even though it isn't complicated. Some of the other ones I've seen just look like the minimum. My only suggestion would be to find a way to make it interesting, but hide the actual patch work, as if it were an actual app that was being marketed. You wouldn't want the people who bought it to see all that wiring. Other than that, great job!

This colorful and all-around pleasing patch was a pleasure to see! The toggle turns on a cute song that after 2 bars goes into 8 beats of a similar sequence of the same melody. I honestly am not quite sure about how some of the things in it worked-but that's a compliment! It seems like a great next step to the simple sequencer assignment, so good job taking it to the next level! There were different counters involved, so I assume that is how the song went to the different sections. I really enjoyed the feel throughout the project! It was very fun and seemed like something that could be a children's game (I mean that in a good way). I don't know if I could add an improvement other than making sure that you upload your file in the .zip format, it was a great project!

The patch is simple with visual buttons to see the sequence as it plays along with the additional numbers at the bottom that correspond to the keys of the keyboard. It works by hitting the toggle and the sequence plays through and keeps looping until you turn it off. I did not personally know the tune of Onett (before looking it up!) but it sounded nice and concise, made me happy. I suggest cleaning up the keyboard numbers a bit. Instead of on hookup to each number, there can be additional connections to the same note, they will just be played at a different time, depending on where the connection is in the sequence.

This patch was very similar to the tutorial, the only differences I could see were that it used a 16 counter instead of an 8 counter and had some rests/breaks. That said, the tune it played was pretty. I had never heard of the intended song or the game it was from, at least not until I did some googling and realized it was actually part of the "Mother" series. This amused me because I follow a few people on tumblr who are utterly obsessed with the games so I know a bit about it. Anyway, that has nothing to do with the actual patch, but it did improve my overall experience because I was able to connect it to my own life. I did notice that there was both a "make a bleep" and a "bleep" subpatch, and only the "bleep" one was needed, as I was able to delete the former(and it's connections) without the patch being broken.

The patch has a tree branch set up, with the individual buttons stemming from the counter function. This patch did a good job of keeping a clean and professional look. Functionality wise this patch is exemplary. There were no technical issues playing the sequencer and it even had a nice little melody to it. Great patch.
Simple and easy to understand. Very similar to what was shown in class. The patch is neat and works.

The patch runs a simple metro/count/selector that apparently plays the Onett theme from Earthbound, though it's hard to recognize without varying note lengths. There's also an unused make_a_beep subpatch. It's simple and technically proficient. I would work on creating variable note lengths.

Toggle, Color, one metronome, notes, four parts, shifting chords, this does it all! Obvious in depth understanding of the project and creative and interesting development of the work. Well organized and explained, this piece is user friendly and easy on the eyes and ears. Hard to complain about this one, maybe could lead to a longer composition otherwise its bloody fantastic!!!!

As a huge fan of horror movies, I was excited to hear this patch because the word "eerie" was in the title. Upon opening the patch I loved the fact that she used color for the buttons, giving it some aesthetic appeal. I really enjoyed the composition, and it didn't disappoint. It was indeed eerie - something that you'd hear straight out of a paranormal movie. The composition also included more than two notes playing at the same time which went beyond the bare minimum requirements. The combination of individual notes and chords really helped to give it that creepy repetitive feel, and there isn't anything that I would have changed about it.

I like the overall look of this patch. It's easy to navigate and understand what I'm supposed to do to make it function properly. I like how you got different chords to be struck using the metronome. The different colors are helpful for me to see what notes are being activated throughout the melody. You composed a piece of music that is tranquil and not terrible to listen to over and over in any way, that's impressive considering you say you are not a musician or composer. I feel like I'm learning more about Max just watching the buttons light up. I'd suggest composing a longer melody.

Description:
 
 When activated, this patch plays a tune that is the author's original composition. The author makes expert use of polyphony in their work.
 
 
 
 Technical analysis:
 
 When pressed, a toggle sends a bang to a metro that counts every 300 ms. From there, a counter measures every eight counts. If a note is to be played, a message containing the note value is sent to the "make a bleep" sub patch, and then a sine wave is generated. 
 
 
 
 Conceptual analysis:
 
 The piece is actually 4 times longer than I originally thought! It counts through 8 beats four times, not just the same 8 beats. The author is making a very good use of alternating selects and counts in the signal flow- meaning you can divide the piece into beats and measures by having a count that leads to a select that leads to another count that leads to another select. The fact that the first two chords that the piece produces are very similar sounding creates a surprise moment when the last to measures sound completely different. Although the author says in the submission that they are not a musician or composer, I think this piece shows the author has a clear understanding about the technical/ mathematical structure that music and programming have in common. Also, the use of color in max patches is never bad- and at firs glance it looked like the author was simply placing colored buttons at random, they actually match the pitch of the note, which is a great way to convey to the user what is being activated when a sound is played.
 
 
 
 Improvement:
 
 The only improvement that I can see with the patch is to take a look at the select object at the furthest left. The comment pointing to it suggests that there is a rest on the 8th beat, but the 8th beat is actually not a rest, a note is played. Other than that there is nothing of a technical nature wrong with the patch. One thing that the author should do, however, is be more confident in this work! There is no need to lower expectations by suggesting in the submission that you're not a composer because you've created a wonderful composition here. And in the patch there is a comment saying "I attempt a chord..", but in reality the author succeeded in creating that chord! This is a great work and the author should be proud of it- there is no need to be timid about this effort.
The patch looked well organized and presentable. I thought the sound was decent and could tell there was a nice amount of effort put in it. I was recommend dolling it up a little more next time.

Your idea and concept are very simple, but the sounds that are chosen are funny to me for some odd reason. It sounds like the George Lopez theme song without the trumpets and if it was slowed down a bit. I think the actual idea of how you wanted to present this is different from what a lot of other people decided to do and the sound is a little bit low on this DC Lab computer for some reason, but it's still a good patch. Everything with the technical analysis is fine, even though your sound is coming out without one of those buttons to stop and play sounds, which I didn't expect.

When they described that they had the "least amount of musical talent", I thought hey I can't be that bad. The patch looks very nicely displayed and is concise. It shows the notes playing on a piano and acts as a nice visual. The patch worked perfectly, it played all the notes in the right order and repeated the sequence. It didn't really sound like a recognizable song but it could easily be turned into a new creation. I thought it was also funny how the person wrote Warning, I have no musical talent. Don't worry, it worked fine and I thought it was nice and simple tune.

This patch is great. There is a lot going on and it sounds great. The layout is cool and they used commands that I wasn't familiar with. If anything they could organize the patch a little differently, but overall I really liked what they did.

This piece is very simple, and just plays a short repetitive tune. The work is activated with a single toggle, then plays through its various other components. It's a simple concept, and didn't really spark any specific feelings. I think this work may have come out a little better with a bit more effort, and a longer melody.

The patch plays a simple melody on a loop. That is just the beginning though, because there are some really cool objects in it. Plot~ and Picslider objects added some fun to looking at and playing with this patch. The picslider made the patch interactive, because you could click and drag the button and that would change the sound. I loved the Plot~ because it bounced to the music and was visually appealing. The patch is super cool but the electronic sound and short repetition wasn't too pleasant to listen to.

This patch is easy to understand and produces a simple melody. It uses multiple bleeps and two counters to create a simple 8-note melody. Technically, the patch uses things that are not necessary, such as showing numbers multiple times and using + operators instead of a message of the specific number that was desired. The 'select' has 3.14 and 10, which are never received from the counter. The second counter goes backwards yet never hits 1, 3.14, or 8, as the select has in it. While it doesn't affect the way the patch works, removing those things would make it easier to understand. Conceptually, the patch seems like it demonstrates knowledge of how a sequencer works yet doesn't create sounds that are great to hear. I would suggest removing unnecessary elements and trying to make the bleeps into a basic recognizable song.

Very nice. It is clean looking, sounding and works right out of the box. I also like your creative use of more complex objects. Harmonically it sounds great. One thing though is that with how well and neat your patch is I bet you could have had more amorphous interesting melody.

First of all, it took me a second to realize you sent more than the actual project required. I got a max patch for four things, which is going above and beyond but it's totally cool. For the max patch I think I am supposed to critique, it was simple and intricate. There were no visual or technical problems with how your project worked. I just want to know why you sent the "make a bleep" patch and the other two. Still, your patch is very intricate and simple, which is a good thing. It made me feel anger because I thought I was going to have to critique four different patches, but at the end of the day, I'm very chill. My only suggestion is to not have a folder of work, only what is needed.
This was a cool little melody. However, the last four notes don't play for some reason. Besides that, great job! Maybe try adding in chords or using rests!

I like your work. Not too hard but not too easy. I don't know if you know but the last five buttons aren't connected so no sound is made. It was very clean and basic and I feel like you successfully made a sequencer. One suggestion would be to go a little out of your comfort zone and try something a little harder than a few keys. But overall, good work.

Well done! This looks like it was a bit complex to set up, but it works like a charm. Everything is labeled, your layout is fantastic, and its fully interactive. I dont feel like I have anything I could suggest to you to make it better than it already is. I told someone else this, but If you had gone throw and changed the colors of everything that might have been cool.

A little overwhelming to look at upon first glance but I love the idea. There are three sound files that play according to which gate the user decides to open. Each sound represents a drum sound which are clearly labeled on the sides. There is also a clear set of instructions that allows for ease of use. It works when a gate is switched on and the beat repeats but can be changed accordingly based on what gate the user opens or leaves closed. The author created a neat basis of beats that could be easily changed up from a simple click. It was fun, trying to think I had a good sense of rhythm but it was definitely exciting to jam out to after. For an improvement I think it would be neat to add a few more sounds even though it was totally awesome with just three.

At first glance I said "oh Sh&* but It was interesting. Im not sure if I did it correctly but It seemed like a lot of work for the minimal sounds I actually heard. But it did work correctly and it was pretty cool. It took some time to change the sounds to make it unique but it works great and is pretty interesting. One suggestion is possibly trying something to randomly change which sounds go where to add to the variety of choices. Great work.

Great attempt at a Roland Tr-909! This patch sequences three types of drum sounds. It uses gates as a user interface to turn on or off a sound within the sequence. A master volume slider and levelmeters objects made it easier to use. This is a very successful patch and is super fun to play with. I have played with it on two separate days. Both times I had trouble making sure all the sound files were available for the patch to use. There was file inside a file and once I loaded all the sounds from both files and the patch to the desktop the patch worked flawlessly. Even with the directions it took a while to get it to work. This would be a great one for presentation mode because it would visually simplify the user interface.

The patch plays a blues tune using a two-part sequencer, with each part moving at a different speed and containing a different number of steps. Everything visually looks like what we did in class, but for some reason I'm having trouble manipulating it correctly such that I can hear both sequences instead of only the 64-step one; I played with the patch quite a bit but couldn't figure out what was wrong. I'm interested conceptually in the idea of representing a blues standard through Max, but I wish I was able to see the full effect. The author might improve the work by thoroughly testing the patch to avoid such issues, and perhaps by organizing it in a more visually accessible way (I had to scroll quite a bit horizontally before I could see what was going on).

This patch is really complicated and doesn't have to have so many elements that are on it. The buttons are not needed in your patch so it would have been easier for you to just connect the selectors to the messages directly. The patch is also very big and could have been shrunk down. If you were to use it again it would be really hard to copy. I really like the song I think it has a very interesting tempo with all the pauses but its suppose to be blues so I get why it's the way it is. I think your patch could also be more fun for the user if you were to change anything about it I would add some visual elements or some ways for the user to interact with it. Especially with blues music, a lot of it is improvised so you could add some other tones to it that the user could press to play.

My initial reaction was that this patch was massive, not necessarily a bad thing though, it was evident it probably took a lot of tweaking to get right. There were a substantial amount of notes. The patch uses two different metronomes and a series of notes to create a blues song. The song sounded pretty cool, it was enjoyable to listen to and by the author's description I could tell it probably took a while to perfect. I did notice some unnecessary parts. The blank message boxes used to create rests/breaks weren't exactly needed, those select outputs could have just been left empty, which would have helped with the size of the patch as well. I think you would have done so if you knew though, as it probably would have saved you some extra work!

This patch is very big. The sequencer didn't fit the screen. However, it still retained the clean and functional look. When the sequencer is activated, a really jazzy melody begins to play. This patch did a great job utilizing the tools to make a cool melody.

Your patch huge width wise. The sounds kind of sounded like something from an old game which i liked. I don't know if its possible but I would suggest somehow making it so everything is visible on the screen or at least most of it at a time.

Overall of your patch looks great and complicated, The template that you picked is so catchy, however you might need to do more research on how to embed the URL link into Max. My suggestion to you is that you might add the cougar sound(like the original version) into your project by adding .wav file instead of playing just midi note. This will make your project so much more interesting in the way that you want. I believed that you put a lot of effort in to this work because your patch is well crafted, however there is a part that it seems not working to me, which is the ""Extra piece" otherwise everything is awesome.
I like the melody in this patch it has good pacing and nice soothing sound. I like the complexity of this patch and how well it is put together. This is a good patch overall and I like it.

Very very nice patch. This patch was very organized. The patch looked complicated but all I had to do is toggle it on and it worked flawlessly. The melody was amazing as was the entire work. I have nothing but praise for this work. If I was forced I would ask for graphics or visuals, but I didn't feel like I needed it.

So it looks like there's three different sequencers that make up different parts of the song. Everything is laid out very cleanly. I particularly like the left most one; it's actually really aesthetically pleasing to look at. I think this setup was a smart way of making sure all those notes didn't look too clustered. It works very simply, which I like. The metronome sets off three different sequencers, and that's basically it. It's very simple technically, although I'm sure it took a lot of skill to actually organize all of those notes together. I really liked the song created it was very pleasing to listen to. Also, I checked out the song (definitely putting that on my iPod) and I think they did a really good job of matching the song. I can't imagine doing that without actual sheet music or midi notes (major kudos!). The only suggestion I have for improving the work is that you could put in some synth sounds if you use the techniques we learned from the last assignment along with this. One of the other assignments I critiqued used a sequencer to set off sound files in a specific order to create a beat, so you could try and do that to achieve the same sound as the original song if you wanted.

I think this was supposed to be Surfin' USA. The patch was too big to fit in the Max window on my laptop. There wasn't a toggle so it just started playing as soon as it was opened. I'm not sure what the blue blinking dots were for, but I can appreciate trying to give the patch a little sprucing up.
Gotta love the Beach Boys! The Led visualization was a nice touch and the patch was simple enough to understand. Although, I feel like the tempo was a bit off.

The patch has an unusual structure to it in that much of the commands and objects are quite miniaturized and on the sides while these giant bright blue buttons, acting as a sensor that detects sound and lights up, are front-and-center. It's highly unusual, but a fun idea, especially given the upbeat tempo and message of the Beach Boys' music, before Pet Sounds, that is. The structure of the mechanics of the patch are very routine, there being an interval command, though, that slightly changes the tune every pass-through, which makes it interesting to listen to time-after-time. The Beach Boys are a classic staple of music, and Surfin' USA was and is the epitome of the surfing scene so I quite enjoy listening to it repeatedly. For improvement I suggest reorganizing the patch hierarchy to make the actual technical aspect more understandable.

This patch looked so crazy and complicated and I am astounded! The sound was very nice and creative and I would recommend it to a friend. I think they could have advanced a little more only because I see more to be accomplished.

This is my favorite patch so far. Although on the bigger side, this patch offers a visual accompaniment to the carefully thought out melody that the sequencer plays. The added visual aspect lets me get a better feel for the melody and is a great addition.

After clicking download, the patch did not load as a typical patch would. Instead of showing the presentation, it went straight to the coding of it. I am not sure if this was because of my computer or because of the way it was saved. However, I can tell by the coding that work was indeed put into it! It's a shame that it didn't show up, I'm a huge fan of the song Earth Angel, and since the author is a pianist, I'm sure it was done very well! But since I wasn't able to see it, I can't say these things for sure.
It won't open correctly. Maybe before submitting assignment try to close and open it so see if it works. Im jsut getting a bunch of Hooplah.

Well despite your challenges you did the required work for the patch so that's good. It was very simple in its function and that is not a bad thing. I can clearly see you tried to make a somewhat discernible melody using this labyrinthine software. My only suggestion would be to practice with Max a bit more. It seems like foreign calligraphy right now but once it clicks with you how it works it will be much easier to use. That being said, Max will never stop being frustrating in general, as I have learned.

When I click "Download" I am taken to a page containing endless text computer script. I'm not sure why this is happening, as all 4 of the other patches I just critiqued downloaded fine without any problems. Not sure if this is a technical error or some kind of error made by the creator of this patch, but unfortunately I have nothing to critique. Oh no! I can't see this one either, when I press download I get redirected to a block of code. Sorry, especially since you had to redo everything :(

The Ramones are AWESOME! The sequencer very well designed and was not too complicated to understand, which left me feeling relieved from the other complicated designs I've critiqued. The tune was just as enjoyable as the sequencer and it did do justice towards the original song. The time it took to create the sequencer must have been awhile, which shows through the original composition of the sequencer. To be honest, I don't know what I could say to the author to improve his/her work on this project besides adding moving graphics. This is an introductory course yet others have shown to have more experience patching on the Max program. The author is clearly ahead of the game with the project and it ROCKS!
The notes seem to be all correct in accordance to the song, and the patch works quite well. The only thing is, maybe slow the tempo down a tiny bit.

Since you do have so many notes playing the side structure was a good idea. The button flashes directed and visually represented the song. The song is recognizable through the patch. I also commend you for attaching all the connections.

This patcher appeared more complicated than it really was. I liked the beat and it was very catchy. I could see how making it was a challenge but it was very entertaining. I have been recommending for everyone to make it colorful and stuff of that sort just to appeal to the eye more.

Really dug the melody and bass. I can see you took your time with this patch finding the right notes, which I know is a pain in the ass. Technically it was very simple. I had fun switching one part off and back on, changing the variation of both sequences playing together, and it worked. My only suggestion would be maybe incorporating midi and finding other sounds. Thats not really much of a suggestion, I'm just required to make a suggestion. I liked it!

The patch used the make a bleep with a grouping of selects, counters, and metros. What was unique for me about this patch, was the dual melodies that could be played either together or separately without there seeming to be something lacking. The author even enabled the user to quite easily hear each side separately or together. In the future it isn't necessary to make duplicate metros and counters, instead make a single master time system, and the use send and receives to move timing data to the selects. Then to make one side play and not the other, add gates between the receive and the select with a button hooked to the left inlet. With this setup you can hit the button to allow numbers to pass to the select, and you never have to worry about one side being out of sync with the other.

When I opened it, I was quite surprised at how massive it was, leading to how the creator put a lot of work into this. Technically, The lead part seems to work fine but I will say that the rhythm could barely be heard and had to listen closely to even hear it. The author created a song utilizing two seperate selects for rhythm and command, and it felt alright to use. I suggest to raise the volume on the rhythm section a little bit, but it's pretty good overall!

As the description says, there is both a lead and rhythm section that the user can activate one or the other or both at the same time. Both pieces of music are enjoyable for listening on a loop and sound great together. It's nice to have the ability to play with the tempo of each by having the number object attached to the metronome. This allows the user to experience with different speeds to adjust how it sounds. I've had it playing in the background for about 10 minutes now and haven't gotten annoyed at all, good job.

Based off of the description that was written for this project, I was able to determine that this patch would have two different sections for a piece of music to be played, a lead part and a rhythm part. Both of these parts would be able to be played separately or collectively. The description ensures this by naming both sides and by saying that the users can do this on their own.
 
 
 
 The way that this patch works is that it is activated by clicking on the top toggle. The toggle then activates the two lower toggles, the two buttons and two metro objects which then activate the counters, which range from 1-32 on each side. The counters are attached to two different sets of select objects which are numbered from 1-32. These objects then obtain the information they need in order to play whatever note with the use of a numbered message attached to each input. The number was attached to each input, is then attached to a number object, which shows what number it received. This object is then attached to a subpatch that plays different midi notes based off of the individual number message it receives, it makes a sound. Then, to toggle the sound on and off, there is an ezdac object attached to each side.
 
 
 
 The author created a simple song with the use of 2 different set of notes. Their sequencer branched out into two different sides, one representing the lead, the other representing the rhythm. By including toggles on both sides as well as a top toggle, it is possible to listen to these part together or to just the listen lead or to just the rhythm just as the description said would be possible. Going over this patch was very easy and convenient due to the separate toggles on each side and due to the labeling of what was the lead and the rhythm that was on each side.
 
 
 
 My only concrete suggestion is that I believe that it would be possible for the author to omit the number object that is attached to the metro objects on both sides. It does not really serve a purpose and when I was just trying it out to affect the patch, it turned the notes into a jumble of sounds, rather than a song.

The patch is very interesting to look at. It almost looks like a wreaking ball and acts as the visual element to the song it plays. It is also looks simple to create and not very complicated. I think the creator made a good choice to use the chorus of the song. It would have been interesting to hear the full song with the background music and all. The author created a computerized version of a popular song with both a visually appealing element and musically adept part.

From first glance it looks really clean and seems to work correctly. It was a cool way to make the song and it was very easy to tell how it worked. You successfully made a song from a sequencer and that was the assignment so great work. One suggestion would be to add something to make some of the notes last longer to give the song some depth. But overall, great work.

This sequencer is very elaborate and looks very overwhelming at first. Though, upon clicking play I can see that other then changing tempo you really didn't do all to much extra stuff. It works nicely, I'm not very knowledgable of the actual song but I'm sure it sounds about like that. I think with the synthesizer piano visible in this, it could have been really cool to see the keys play the song.

Terrible song choice. You could've chosen a better song. Out of all the songs in the world, you chose wrecking ball by Miley Citrus? I must say I'm disappointed actually. This patch made me feel agitated, which is unfortunate since I was having a great day before listening to this song. Now my whole day is just going to go into a downward spiral from hear on out. It's stuck in my head now. Anyways, I think you did a good job with this. I like how you added pauses in the sequencer to match up how the actual song is. It was very easy to understand due to labeling. My suggestion would be to choose a better song.

A single toggle runs to three metro/counter/select combinations, which each lead to a make_a_beep. The sound certainly has a spooky vibe to it, with sort of a eerie music box feel. The only change I would make would be to clean up the patch some - there's no need to have three separate metro/counter/selects if all the metros are the same.

Based solely off of the description that this project has, it is very clear on what the goal is, which is to make "music" using internal synthesizers. There was no possible way for me to misunderstand what the author was trying to accomplish.
 
 
 
 The way that this patch works is that it is activated by clicking on the top toggle. The toggle then activates the three metro objects and three buttons which then activate the counters, which range from 1-8 on all three sides. The counters are attached to three different sets of select objects which are numbered from 1-8, that are also attached to 8 buttons on each branch. These objects then obtain the information they need in order to play whatever note with the use of a numbered message attached to each input. The number was attached to each input, is then attached to a number object, which shows what number it received. This object is then attached to a subpatch that plays different midi notes based off of the individual number message it receives, it makes a sound. Then, to toggle the sound on and off, there is an ezdac object attached to all three sides.
 
 
 
 The author successfully created a sequencer that played a tune that was inspired by the Halloween season. The way that notes were arranged really made it sound like it was a haunting tune. The three different branches that this patch had served as a way to make chords happen. The patch itself is really clean and I can hardly see any faults with it.
 
 
 
 My only concrete suggestion would be that if it's possible would you be able to possibly condense your three branches down to two by maybe placing the two numbered messages on a single input?

I love the simplicity of the design. It doesn't look over the top and does exactly what the assignment asked you to do. The patch uses a metro object to output numbers into a make a bleep object. The patch makes me feel that Max isn't something to be afraid of and that anyone could use it to make something useful or entertaining. I would suggest adding user input into the patch so that anyone could make their own loop.

Description:
 
 This piece produces a dissonant piece that reminds the viewer of the music from "Nightmare Before Christmas".
 
 
 
 Technical Analysis:
 
 When the user selects a toggle, the piece activates 3 separate metros which count in sections of 8 beats. If a note is to be played, a select sends a message containing the note value to the "make a bleep" sub patch which produces sine wave.
 
 
 
 Conceptual analysis:
 
 I don't know if this was intentional, but the way that the buttons blink with that intense yellow along with the music reminds me of the halloween decorations that have little blinking light for eyes. 
 
 Anyway, this patch does a very efficient job a creating a haunting piece of music for the user. It's really easy to see how everything is ordered, and how the patch works.
 
 
 
 Suggestion:
 
 This is just a wild and crazy thing, but I noticed that the whole point of the piece is creating a dissonant, creepy, tune- and the notes seem to group together. So, one suggestion might be that, instead of listing each individual message for the for the note, you could elevate this piece by connecting them to a random number generator instead. That way, not only does this piece become something that is new and exciting every time someone uses is, it plays to the strengths of using a computer to make music- like the fact that computers can generate their own note values.

This patch is really neat. The sequencer plays a very catchy song that is really popular now. They nailed the melody and it sounds exactly like the real song. They even added a vocal to make the sequencer more advanced. Overall this patch is very functional but also adds a fun side.

Visually and functionally this piece was very strong. This was the only piece that I saw that incorporated the mini key board, which gives it a heightened level visually. I also really liked that you incorporate notes and a voice over wave file creating the additional layers. Technically the piece is very intricate, with the two different counter sets 1-34, yet the simplification by the clean design make it easy for the user to follow, as well as engaging. Another element that I really like was the meter, it was a nice added visual component to the piece. I think you put a lot of time and effort into this work and it shows. One way to elevate it might be to create another metro box on the second counter layer and change the speed slightly to create a different effect. Great work!

The patch is easy to read and understand, I like the use of the "open" function for the spoken word, and how the notes play only after the words have spoken. The timing is on point, and everything flows well together, overall I think this patch is very solid and the use of spoken word makes it interesting.

When I first heard this song I started laughing. Something about hearing a song like "Talk Dirty To Me" in a Max patch is just funny. The patch works as in was intended to do and the layout is clean. This was probably my favorite one out of the 5 I reviewed because it was hilarious! Good job.

Hah! Awesome job for completing the assignment with an easy to follow max patch and creative output. I appreciate incorporating another sample in time with your midi sequencer. I appreciate the integrated use of metro and counter and it really seems you've got the know-how to program a sequencer in Max. 
 
 
 
 If you had more time to factor in beat samples or create synthesizers I would be anxious to see what you come up with. Great patch!

At first glance, it looked simple enough. I didn't know what a few of the objects were but once I started using it, I figured it all out. Other than that it was fairly straightforward.
