This patch was a simple, yet very well done 10 note sequencer. It features two different meters to measure sound, which was very fun to see. It also had a background color changer to help make it seem customizable to the audience/user. Overall, the patch was a clear and precise way to sequence the music files, and the little spices added in made it a lot more fun. My only suggestion for an improvement would just be to possibly make a more recognizable melody for the sequence to play, but that's just being nitpicky. Other than that, it's great!

Patch was very easy to read, looks very similar to class example, although the colors and various meters added make it aesthetically pleasing. Over the patch ran but the sounds were a bit boring, but I enjoyed the customizable options you added. Maybe making the bleeps go to a certain song would make this patch a bit better.

Description:
 
 This piece plays a simple 8 note tune when activated.
 
 
 
 Technical Analysis:
 
 Then the user selects the toggle, it begins a metro with only 150 ms delay between beats. That activates a sub patch which contains a 1 to 8 counter. Then a select object sends a message containing the note value back to the main patch which generates a saw wave.
 
 
 
 Conceptual analysis:
 
 The inclusion of a saw rather than a sine wave, with its gritty, mechanical tone color, plays well with the fact that the notes in the tune seems really "techno" and "computer-y". 
 
 
 
 Suggestion:
 
 In Tinapple's "make a bleep" patch, he included a message and a line object with the sine wave object that decays the tone over the length of the note. That would be useful in this patch because when the metro is turned off, it continues to produce a tone. It's hard to tell if you were going to a specific tune or just random notes, but if it was just random, you could include a random number generator that would greatly expand the scope of the project.
Not much work appeared to be put into this patch. It played a little jingle but nothing to impressive. I would recommend playing around with the keys more and trying to have fun with it.

Very organized and easy to look at. The sound is pretty obnoxious but it has that deadmau5 electro ring to it. Very amusing. Maybe on eway to improve would be making it so that the user can choose what notes to be played in order to create a more personal melody.

This piece is more abstract than others, due to use of a sawtooth oscillator. The work is activated by a toggle, then just goes through a simple sequencer like we went over in class, but is put through the oscillator just before final output. I like how it turned out, and it sort of reminded me of an old arcade game fight scene. Overall I thought it was good, but I wouldn't have minded if it were a slightly longer melody.

This patch built on the make a bleep setup, playing an 8 note loop. After the make a bleep section, a sawtooth wave generator was added to the patch. Unfortunately the saw~ made the sound a little bit abrasive and even after the toggle was off, I was getting sawtooth noise from the patch. In the future play around with the attributes of the object more rather than just dropping it into the patch. MSP has many synthesizer objects and all of them can do great things when you take the time to play with them.

This looks fantastic. If only It sounded as good. I think it is compelling how you set this up though because you can potentiall create melody, counter melody, harmony, and even triads. I was not able to get any audio out of it though. Also speaking from experience on 808/909 style step sequencers having a simple "on-off" versus a potentiometer style nob creates easier playability.

So the patch looked cool when I opened it up. I don't often see more than the basic patch so I was excited to see one so different...until I couldn't figure out what to do. I turned it on and it beeped, the same note over and over again on three lines and I found that I could raise the volume, change the notes and make it go faster, but it didn't really follow the instructions. It was supposed to play a song, not leave the user to figure out how to make the song. In the end it just confused me. I would suggest at least giving some instructions on what exactly to do because even after playing around with it for a while, I couldn't really do anything with it. Still a cool design though.

Excellent layout. Perfect organization, nice colors, clear and big font, and nice volume bars and note selecting knobs placed throughout the patch. 
 
 
 
 The patch works by turning it "on," which then begins a piano note going at a steady tempo. The tempe bar at the top controls the beats per minute, there are three sustain bars included each with their own volume bar, and three rows of sixteen knobs to control what notes are being played. 
 
 
 
 I absolutely love the fact that this is an interactive piece in which the user is improvising a piece of music right on the spot. It's genuinely fun to play around with and spend time tweaking to see what type of chord progression comes out of it all. 
 
 
 
 I have no advice to offer on how to improve this, you've made a wonderful patch. Though, if there was a way to select between different midi instruments, that'd make it even more awesome.

I was stunning by the cool graphic in the presentation mode. I think that the overall of your patch looks really great, but the sequence of the note is quite simple. I think it would be great if make a default note sequence more like a musical sequence. The adjustable on your project is the strongest point. I believed that you put a lot of effort in to this work because your patch is well crafted, but it would be better if you can add more creativity to make it more vibrant.

Visually this is the best patch I have seen. It is very pleasing to the eye. Maybe one way to improve this would be to put in different keys so its not just the same note repeating over and over again.

The last couple sentences of your theory are worded confusingly. You should add more of the equations to the theory. Could do another study or two. In your conclusion I would talk more about the drag forces and motion than the code itself.

I would recommend getting a little deeper with your study and results, just by manipulating the factors in the drag equation and explaining the way the code behaves under these changes. There a few minor grammatical errors I noticed in the conclusion so I would go ahead and review that, but overall the report was easy to read and fairly well done.

1. Technical accuracy and completeness of theory and computations
 
 (a) All equations used in this project were properly described within the theory of the report.
 
 (b) Program runs correctly and displays numbers within the ranges of expected values.
 
 (c) Code runs, but is not explicitly verified within the body of the report. More emphasis could be placed on why the output makes sense for given input values.
 
 (d) Only the initial conditions chosen by the user were inputted into the code. Further calculations and results were not described within the report.
 
 
 
 2. Depth, interest, insight and scientific integrity of the study
 
 (a) The introduction clearly introduces the topic of the assignment and what concept this code is trying to convey. It is concise and short, but provides all necessary information for an uninformed reader to follow.
 
 (b) Since there was very little varying of parameters, the study possessed little depth and significance. The code runs correctly, but what does the output say about the study? About drag force?
 
 (c) No new information is given from further computations.
 
 (d) Conclusion vaguely covers scientific study, but does not go into detail.
 
 
 
 3. Quality of the report
 
 (a) The users English is sufficient, and the read runs very smoothly and effortlessly. Transitions are easy to distinguish and the topics flow together throughout the entire report.
 
 (b) Though I could reproduce the calculations shown, there are very little to warrant any great understanding from simply doing so.
 
 (c) The conclusion is somewhat vague, but conveys the major concepts and connects with the report.
 
 (d) The report looks professional. Graphs and tables are not simply thrown together, descriptions are placed in appropriate places, and sections flow from one to the next.

Discuss what it means, how it is achieved, and see if you can model it through your code. Does the code give you values consistent with the definition of terminal velocity. Try to do this by messing with the parameters of the drag force equation. At some point in your report, try to mention how this is relevant, outside of class, to real world engineering problems.
